- IT Tools for analysis and design. Experience Sr. Business System Analyst | Team Lead Fiserv May 2014  – Present (1 year 4 months) Heredia, Costa Rica Sr. Business System Analyst is mainly in charge of: 
•	Identifying stakeholders and facilitates discussions or workshops with the purpose of eliciting and understanding stakeholder needs, requirements, and priorities. 
•	Formulating the functional specifications that implement the behaviors described by the vision in the manner prescribed by the User experience design. 
•	Documenting the functional specifications completely and unambiguously, satisfying the needs of development, quality assurance, technical communicators, and other internal customers and stakeholders. 
•	From project or feature vision through product delivery, facilitates and maintains requirements traceability 
•	Reviewing development and quality assurance artifacts for traceability purposes 
•	Participating in User Acceptance Testing to confirm that the coded product successfully implements the software specifications and User experience design. 
 
Team Lead is mainly in charge of: 
•	Lead teams in the design of new applications, configuration of system upgrades and development of new programming tools. 
•	Attending and participating in team meetings. 
•	Create business processes, best practices, standards, templates and operating procedures to optimize IT project development. 
•	Assign schedules, coordinate staff and allocate resources to ensure efficiency and productivity is maximized. 
•	Giving prompt and accurate information on individual staff member performance. 
•	Develop metrics to test and monitor applications, ensuring consistent improvement. 
•	Collaborate with system architects, software engineers and IT management to ensure projects meet strategic initiatives. 
•	Coordinate with external technology vendors, internal staff members and third party consultants. 
•	Ensuring a clean, safe and friendly working environment. 
•	Reporting to senior managers.  Solutions Quality Analyst Intel Corporation April 2013  –  May 2014  (1 year 2 months) Costa Rica The Solutions Quality Analyst (SQA) plans, facilitates, and conducts the testing. In larger projects, they partner with a Systems Analyst lead to complete these activities. SQA’s develop use cases, test cases, test scenarios, and/or prototypes and are heavily involved in test execution and resolving issues and defects identified. The SQA measures or defines measurements and ensures system and data quality attributes of systems and software applications throughout the Product Life Cycle; from the exploration phase through the end-of-life of a production business solution. They ensure project teams comply with the applicable procedures, standards, and methodologies. The SQA interacts with cross-functional teams to identify, prioritize, and help resolve QA/test related project and/or process problems. The SQA partners with stakeholders and System Analysts (SA’s) to clarify and finalize production/application requirements. The SQA provides input to the development team to establish configuration management systems and to establish the software release process. IT System Analyst Intel Corporation January 2013  –  May 2014  (1 year 5 months) Costa Rica Work with Business Analyst clients to clarify business requirements, map them to systems capabilities, and recommend technical solutions. Convert client requirements into technical terms for the development team, and advise clients on resource requirements, scope, budgets, and timing. Develop use cases, customer scenarios, and/or demos, and plan and coordinate testing of the newly developed or enhanced applications between the business and the development teams. Document changes and create troubleshooting guides if needed. Work on several projects simultaneously in teams with other Systems Analysts and developers. Technical leader specializing in the development of test cases and the application thereof, to the new versions of existing software in the area of ​​manufacturing, management techniques and technologies, and excellent management of working as a team with developers and end users, ensuring product quality and communication end key members.

Experience Solutions Quality Analyst Intel Corporation February 2014  – Present (1 year 7 months) Folsom, California The Solutions Quality Analyst (SQA) plans, facilitates, and conducts the testing. In larger projects, they partner with a Systems Analyst lead to complete these activities. The SQA measures or defines measurements and ensures system and data quality attributes of systems and software applications throughout the Product Life Cycle; from the exploration phase through the end-of-life of a production business solution. They ensure project teams comply with the applicable procedures, standards, and methodologies. The SQA interacts with cross-functional teams to identify, prioritize, and help resolve QA/test related project and/or process problems. The SQA provides input to the development team to establish configuration management systems and to establish the software release process. 
 
The SQA reviews plans, designs, specifications, and other records and generates quality-related documentation. The SQA continuously evaluates life cycle processes and methodology and works with stakeholders to drive improvements for the overall project quality. The SQA also inspects delivered components, identifies and assures resolution of product defects, and participates in and/or manages verification and validation testing. The SQA is responsible for ensuring the readiness of the test environment and tools required for testing and validating the software product.  
 
The SQA generates quality plans (including data quality) that identify acceptance criteria as well as risks and gaps and outlines testing priorities that are traceable to design and requirements. They monitor implementation progress and health through various metrics and indicators. SQA's document the test results to influence project release decisions. In general, they monitor releases through the life cycle and perform testing analysis for continuous improvement to reduce future operational costs. Support Specialist Intel September 1997  –  January 2014  (16 years 5 months) Folsom, California Support Specialists (ITSS) provide first, second, and/or third level customer support for enterprise applications and systems based on service level agreements. They support internal employees, and/or external customers/suppliers globally. The ITSS documents and troubleshoots problems for resolution. The ITSS must become familiar with the systems they support and with current business processes.  
 
ITSS's provide or coordinate training to internal employees, peers, or other levels of support (e.g., Level 1) and provide subject matter expertise to training departments. ITSS's may collaborate with other groups and organizations to: provide service for infrastructure changes, foster partnerships with other levels of support, elevate data quality concerns, share BKM's and information, communicate known system problems, and keep abreast of upcoming developments.  
 
ITSS's may be required to provide auxiliary support to the IT Emergency Response Process in the event of a Cyber Security incident or other emergency situation that impacts the availability and/or overall stability of IT products and/or services. The SQA measures or defines measurements and ensures system and data quality attributes of systems and software applications throughout the Product Life Cycle; from the exploration phase through the end-of-life of a production business solution. They ensure project teams comply with the applicable procedures, standards, and methodologies. The SQA interacts with cross-functional teams to identify, prioritize, and help resolve QA/test related project and/or process problems. The SQA provides input to the development team to establish configuration management systems and to establish the software release process. 
 
The SQA reviews plans, designs, specifications, and other records and generates quality-related documentation. The SQA continuously evaluates life cycle processes and methodology and works with stakeholders to drive improvements for the overall project quality. The SQA also inspects delivered components, identifies and assures resolution of product defects, and participates in and/or manages verification and validation testing. The SQA is responsible for ensuring the readiness of the test environment and tools required for testing and validating the software product.  
 
The SQA generates quality plans (including data quality) that identify acceptance criteria as well as risks and gaps and outlines testing priorities that are traceable to design and requirements. They monitor implementation progress and health through various metrics and indicators. SQA's document the test results to influence project release decisions. In general, they monitor releases through the life cycle and perform testing analysis for continuous improvement to reduce future operational costs. Support Specialist Intel September 1997  –  January 2014  (16 years 5 months) Folsom, California Support Specialists (ITSS) provide first, second, and/or third level customer support for enterprise applications and systems based on service level agreements. They support internal employees, and/or external customers/suppliers globally. The ITSS documents and troubleshoots problems for resolution. The ITSS must become familiar with the systems they support and with current business processes.  
 
ITSS's provide or coordinate training to internal employees, peers, or other levels of support (e.g., Level 1) and provide subject matter expertise to training departments. ITSS's may collaborate with other groups and organizations to: provide service for infrastructure changes, foster partnerships with other levels of support, elevate data quality concerns, share BKM's and information, communicate known system problems, and keep abreast of upcoming developments.  
 
ITSS's may be required to provide auxiliary support to the IT Emergency Response Process in the event of a Cyber Security incident or other emergency situation that impacts the availability and/or overall stability of IT products and/or services.
